answers.text: an integrated set of computer software

qas.question: How much data can a DBMS store?

plausible_answers.text: a set of related data and the way it is organized

qas.question: What does a database refer to informally?
What requires a user to use more than one database?
What allows the entry, storage and retrieval of only small quantities of information?
How much data is typically lost by a DBMS?

context: Formally, a "database" refers to <b3_0>a set of related data and the way it is organized<b3_0/>. Access to these data is usually provided <a0_0>by a "<b5_0>database management system<b5_0/>" (<b4_0>DBMS<b4_0/>)<a0_0/> consisting of <a1_0>an integrated set of computer software<a1_0/> that allows users to interact with one or more databases and provides access to all of the data contained in the database (although restrictions may exist that limit access to particular data). The DBMS provides various functions that allow entry, storage and retrieval of <a2_0><b6_0>large quantities<b6_0/><a2_0/> of information and provides ways to manage how that information is organized.
